Content.Description: Paleo-magnetic absolute reference frame.
HotSpot-derived absolute reference frame.
Mantle-derived absolute reference frame.
No-Net-Torque absolute reference frame (new).

The 'Other' type is not the "option #4" which Trond was talking about, ie "relative to any other plate in the hierachy", but rather a way out in case there actually -is- a fourth type which we don't know about.

Enumeration.Description: The type of the crust contained within a boundary.

Content.Description: The interior of a boundary is a region of continental crust.
The interior of a boundary is a region of oceanic crust.
The value of a property is officially unknown; there is no information about which type of crust a boundary is defining.

Enumeration.Description: Enumerates whether a continental boundary is the inner or outer boundary in the broad area of change between continental and oceanic crust.

Content.Description: The boundary defines the Inner edge of the continental boundary (closest to centre of continental crust). For the ClosedContinentalBoundary feature type - note that in the less common case of defining a closed boundary of type=oceanic crust, the "Inner" enumeration still refers to the innermost edge of -Continental- crust.

The boundary defines the Outer edge of the continental boundary (furthest away from centre of continental crust, closest to oceanic crust). For the ClosedContinentalBoundary feature type - note that in the less common case of defining a closed boundary of type=oceanic crust, the "Outer" enumeration still refers to the outermost edge of the -Continental- crust.

The boundary was digitised or imported without any data telling us how the boundary was chosen with regard to inner and outer edges of the continental crust. The value of this property is officially unknown.

Enumeration.Description: Assuming there is a suitable centerLineOf supplied, and understanding that the order of points in the line matters, we can establish a "Left" side and a "Right" side to the .centerLineOf. this property indicates which direction leads to the continental crust.

Content.Description: The continental crust for this PassiveContinentalBoundary can be found to the left, oceanic crust can be found on the right. Depending on the .edge of this PassiveContinentalBoundary, this may also imply some transitional "grey area" crust is on one side or the other.

The continental crust for this PassiveContinentalBoundary can be found to the right, oceanic crust can be found on the left. Depending on the .edge of this PassiveContinentalBoundary, this may also imply some transitional "grey area" crust is on one side or the other.
No information is known about which {continental,oceanic} side is which for this PassiveContinentalBoundary. This property is officially unknown.

Enumeration.Description: The side of the line that the 'dip' is on, giving a hint at what the plane of the surface looks like.

Content.Description: The Plane (e.g. Fault) dips to the 'Left' of this line (relative to the order of points defining the Strike).
The Plane (e.g. Fault) dips to the 'Right' of this line (relative to the order of points defining the Strike).

If the Dip angle of the Plane is 90 degrees (straight down), this property is not clearly defined regardless of its value. For new data, it may be convenient to assign it this "Undefined" value, but bear in mind that when .dipAngle == 90, any value the .dipSide property takes should be considered arbitrary.
The value is officially unknown; there is no information about the dip of the GeologicalPlane (for example, the plane of a Fault's surface).

Enumeration.Description: The motion along the 'dip', or cross-section line of the Fault.

Content.Description: Also called a 'normal' fault. The two sides of the Fault are sliding away from each other.
Also called a 'reverse' fault. The two sides of the Fault are sliding towards each other.
There is no motion along the dip of the Fault.
The value is officially unknown; there is no information about the dip motion.

Enumeration.Description: Type of annotation for a FoldPlane. Appears as symbols along the line of the fold.

Content.Description: Arrows pointing inward.
Arrows pointing outward.
No annotation.
There is no data about the type of the FoldPlane.

Enumeration.Description: The method used to reconstruct feature geometry to paleo times.

Content.Description: Reconstruct using a single 'gpml:reconstructionPlateId'.
Reconstruct using a half-stage rotation between a 'gpml:leftPlate' and 'gpml:rightPlate'.

Enumeration.Description: For Faults with both Dip-Slip and Strike-Slip motion (sometimes termed "Oblique Slip"), this property indicates which of Dip-Slip or Strike-Slip is the primary component of the motion, if any.

Content.Description: The strike motion is the stronger component.
The dip motion is the stronger component.
There is no dominant component.
The value is officially unknown; there is no information about which of Strike-Slip or Dip-Slip is the primary slip component.

Enumeration.Description: The motion along the 'strike', or map-view line of the Fault.

Content.Description: Also called Sinistral motion. When viewed from one side of the Fault, the opposite side appears to be moving to the observer's left.
Also called Dextral motion. When viewed from one side of the Fault, the opposite side appears to be moving to the observer's right.
There is no motion along the strike of the Fault.
The value is officially unknown; there is no information about the strike motion.

Enumeration.Description: Indicates the side of the line that the subducting slab is on. The overriding plate will be on the opposite side. .subductingSlab is an enumeration: Assuming there is a suitable centerLineOf supplied, and understanding that the order of points in the line matters, we can establish a "left" side and a "right" side to the .centerLineOf. this property indicates which of those "left" and "right" sides the subducting slab is on. The overriding plate will be on the opposite side.

Content.Description: The subducting slab is on the left of this SubductionZone, according to the directed gml:LineString .centerLineOf.
The subducting slab is on the right of this SubductionZone, according to the directed gml:LineString .centerLineOf.
The value of is officially unknown; there is no information about which side of the SubductionZone is which.

NativeProperty.Description: A reference to a file in the file system.
A list of latitude/longitude coordinate tuples defining a polyline.
A list of latitude/longitude coordinate tuples defining an unordered set of points.
A list of latitude/longitude coordinate tuples defining a polyline and a '+' or '-' orientation.
A single latitude/longitude coordinate tuple defining a point.
A list of latitude/longitude coordinate tuples defining a closed polyline exterior and zero or more lists of latitude/longitude coordinate tuples each defining an interior hole region.
NativeProperty.Comment: Currently interiors holes are not yet supported in GPlates.

NativeProperty.Description: A grid for which there is an affine transformation between the grid coordinates and the coordinates of an external coordinate reference system. Defined by a grid origin and two offset vectors.
Represents an identifiable position in time.
The period of time the feature is in existence.
NativeProperty.Comment: Consists of two variables, "begin" and "end", which are the points in time (in millions of years ago or Ma) in which the feature came in and out of existence respectively.
"Begin" and "end" can also be set to "Distant Past" and "Distant Future" respectively.

NativeProperty.Description: A sequence of elements of a specified template type.

Property.Name: gpml:absoluteReferenceFrame
Property.Description: Type of absolute reference frame.

Property.Name: gpml:angularRadius
Property.Description: Angular radius.
Property.Comment: This is currently used for small circle radii.

Property.Name: gpml:averageAge
Property.Description: Average magnetisation age (GeologicalTime of magnetisation) based on multiple sites.

Property.Name: gpml:averageDeclination
Property.Description: Average direction in stratigraphic coordinates, declination.

Property.Name: gpml:averageInclination
Property.Description: Average direction in stratigraphic coordinates, inclination.

Property.Name: gpml:averageSampleSitePosition
Property.Description: Average sample-site position (based on multiple sites).

Property.Name: gpml:bandNames
Property.Description: The names of the raster bands in a raster.

Property.Name: gpml:boundary
Property.Description: A static or topological (plate) boundary depending on the feature type.

Property.Name: gpml:centerLineOf
Property.Description: The central line defining the feature's geometry.

Property.Name: gpml:centre
Property.Description: Centre of a small circle.

Property.Name: gpml:conjugate
Property.Description: A reference to the 'pair' or 'twin' of the isochron.
Property.Comment: Due to Isochrons getting split into pieces in PLATES data, it must support more than one conjugate on the other side of the MOR.

Property.Name: gpml:conjugatePlateId
Property.Description: A reference to the plate Id that has the 'pair' or 'twin' of the feature.
Property.Comment: The plate Id is a general-purpose plate Id or specific plate Id for motion of a cluster of Features.

Property.Name: gpml:crust
Property.Description: The type of the crust contained within a boundary.

Property.Name: gml:description
Property.Description: A description of the feature.
Property.Comment: A 'hidden but useful' property inherited from GML.

Property.Name: gpml:dipAngle
Property.Description: Used to describe the angle a surface "dips" from the horizontal, usually in degrees.
Property.Comment: The complete orientation of the plane is the strike (stored in the centerLineOf geometry property), the dip angle (stored in this property), and the dip direction (stored in the dipSide property).
This property is optional. If not present, it indicates that there is no information about the dip available. The property is unspecified or indeterminate.

Property.Name: gpml:dipSide
Property.Description: Used to specify the dip direction of the plane.
Property.Comment: The complete orientation of the plane is the strike (stored in the centerLineOf geometry property), the dip angle (stored in the dipAngle property), and the dip direction (stored in this property).

Property.Name: gpml:dipSlip
Property.Description: The motion along the 'dip', or cross-section line of the Fault.

Property.Name: gpml:domainSet
Property.Description: The region-of-interest of a coverage or raster on which the corresponding 'gpml:rangeSet' is based.
Property.Comment: This is currently only used for rasters.

Property.Name: gpml:edge
Property.Description: Enumerates whether a continental boundary is the inner or outer boundary in the broad area of change between continental and oceanic crust.

Property.Name: gpml:errorBounds
Property.Description: An optional error boundary for the feature.
Property.Comment: Note that we can use LineStrings or Polygons or a combination of both.

Property.Name: gpml:evidence
Property.Description: Features listed as evidence of the HotSpotTrail.
Property.Comment: As a convenience, you may also include references to other gpml:Features here, as the 'evidence' of the HotSpotTrail. These can be the physical features that indicate the path the HotSpot took- Volcanoes, Seamounts, maybe even AseismicRidges - we have to be pretty forgiving with what features the user wants to associate with the HotSpotTrail.

Property.Name: gpml:file
Property.Description: Type of annotation for a FoldPlane. Appears as symbols along the line of the fold.

Property.Name: gpml:foldAnnotation
Property.Description: Type of annotation for a FoldPlane. Appears as symbols along the line of the fold.

Property.Name: gpml:fixedReferenceFrame
Property.Description: The plate Id for which motion is treated as 'fixed'.

Property.Name: gpml:isActive
Property.Description: Time-dependent boolean indicates when the feature is active over time.
Property.Comment: In the case of MidOceanRidge and ContinentalRift, isActive should be "True" if the ridge is actively spreading, and "False" otherwise.
In the case of IslandArc, isActive is "True" if the IslandArc is in the process of being created via subduction, and "False" otherwise.

Property.Name: gpml:islandArc
Property.Description: Multiple small island arcs potentially forming part of a large subduction zone.

Property.Name: gpml:leftPlate
Property.Description: Annotation property describing the plate on the "left" side of the feature.
Property.Comment: Not to be used for reconstruction purposes, as these properties would be an imprecise representation of the crust on each side in many cases. Primarily of interest to the MidOceanRidge feature, where it is used for the purpose of a richer description.

Not a time-dependent property because, for MidOceanRidge at any rate, that's insanity. A MidOceanRidge -generates- crust. For other boundary features, like SubductionZone, this property is only really used as annotation, (i.e. "this SZ is mostly consuming plate 541") and doesn't need to be over-complex.

This property doesn't support multiple plateIds per side for similar reasons to the ones above; in the case of MidOceanRidge, the usefuless of this property hinges on the potential to e.g. interpolate between both sides of the MOR and determine velocity. If more than one plateId per side were supported, topology would have to be taken into consideration, and pieces would have to move at different rates - and so the MOR would have to be broken up into segments, PLATES style. Perhaps when we get segmented MORs in the next release GPGIM, we can consider these extra possibilities. Until then, there's really no point in making this more complex than it needs to be.

Property.Name: gpml:leftUnit
Property.Description: Defines what is on the "Left" side of the contact, using an AbstractRockUnit.
Property.Comment: Assuming there is a suitable centerLineOf supplied, and understanding that the order of points in the line matters, we can establish a "Left" and "Right" side of the centerLine.
Particular implementations of AbstractRockUnit can include BasicRockUnit for simple free-text descriptions plus an extent, or more complex rock unit definitions.

Property.Name: gpml:locationNames
Property.Description: List of location, dredge or drill site names.

Property.Name: gpml:mark
Property.Description: Forms a table of hotspot position and age, using HotSpotTrailMark to represent each row.

Property.Name: gpml:meshPoints
Property.Description: Global positions to calculate plate velocities at.

Property.Name: gpml:motion
Property.Description: The motion along the 'strike', or map-view line of the Transform.

Property.Name: gpml:movingReferenceFrame
Property.Description: The 'conjugate' or 'moving' plate Id.

Property.Name: gpml:multiPosition
Property.Description: When a feature’s geometry is described as a multiple points, it is appropriate to use the MultiPoint geometry.

Property.Name: gml:name
Property.Description: A descriptive name of the feature.
Property.Comment: More than one gml:name can be assigned, the distinction between two names being handled by the 'codeSpace=' attribute of gml:name.

Property.Name: gpml:network
Property.Description: A topological network used to define a deforming region.

Property.Name: gpml:networkMaxEdge
Property.Description: Another parameter to control triangulation quality in a topological network.
Property.Comment: This is a Computational Geometry Algorithms Library (CGAL) parameter.

Property.Name: gpml:networkShapeFactor
Property.Description: Determines the shape (or closeness to being equilateral) the triangles in a topological network triangulation should be.
Property.Comment: This is a Computational Geometry Algorithms Library (CGAL) parameter.

Property.Name: gpml:oldPlatesHeader
Property.Description: Metadata imported from a PLATES data file.
Property.Comment: Since a Feature in GPML will often correspond to a PLATES polyline (if a PLATES file was the original source of data), we include an optional reference to a Plates-compatible header object. This is used to keep metadata around if we import from a PLATES data file.

Property.Name: gpml:outlineOf
Property.Description: Geometry specifying a closed or partial outline.

Property.Name: gpml:pick
Property.Description: An (optional) reference to the MagneticAnomalyIdentification s recorded from this ship track data.
Property.Comment: A feature reference because these data sometimes exist independently of each other, so they should both be gpml:Features.
Optional because you may get a bunch of picks all in close proximity and things stop being clear, odd datasets, etc.

Property.Name: gpml:polarityChronId
Property.Description: The string name of the polarity chron based on the geomagnetic reversal timescale.
Property.Comment: This identifier indicates which Polarity Chron this pick is linked to: other picks on different ship-tracks will share this Id if they belong to the same Chron. e.g. "C34b".

Note that we want this to be unique for each Chron, so the tradition of packing extra info like the 'young/old' value onto the end of the Id ("C34o0.2") is discouraged; polarityChronOffset can be used to store the young/old offset, and any miscellaneous extra information can go in metadata, gml:name, gml:description, or gpml:subcategory as appropriate.
It is called "polarity chron" because it is the 'chron' of all positions sharing the same polarity.

Property.Name: gpml:polarityChronOffset
Property.Description: Specifies the location on the polarity chron, from youngest to oldest.
Property.Comment: A number from 0.0 to 1.0, indicating the proportion from 'young' to 'old'; 0.0 = young, 1.0 = old; This property stores the offset of this pick's chron position compared to the synthetic chron.

Property.Name: gpml:poleA95
Property.Description: Error circle based on uncertainty of the average of pole positions.

Property.Name: gpml:poleDm
Property.Description: VGP uncertainty, meridian.

Property.Name: gpml:poleDp
Property.Description: VGP uncertainty, parallel latitude.

Property.Name: gpml:polePosition
Property.Description: Virtual geomagnetic pole.

Property.Name: gpml:position
Property.Description: When a feature’s geometry is described as a point, it is appropriate to use the Point geometry.

Property.Name: gpml:primarySlipComponent
Property.Description: For Faults with both Dip-Slip and Strike-Slip motion (sometimes termed "Oblique Slip"), this property indicates which of Dip-Slip or Strike-Slip is the primary component of the motion, if any.

Property.Name: gpml:rangeSet
Property.Description: The coverage or raster values at the corresponding 'gpml:domainSet' region-of-interest.

Property.Name: gpml:reconstructionMethod
Property.Description: The method used to reconstruct feature geometry to paleo times.

Property.Name: gpml:reconstructionPlateId
Property.Description: The plateID that will be used for reconstruction purposes.

Property.Name: gpml:relativePlate
Property.Description: The plate that something is relative to.
Property.Comment: This is currently used in MotionPath features as the plate that the motion is relative to.

Property.Name: gpml:rheaFault
Property.Description: Rhea fault.

Property.Name: gpml:rightPlate
Property.Description: Annotation property describing the plate on the "right" side of the feature.
Property.Comment: Not to be used for reconstruction purposes, as these properties would be an imprecise representation of the crust on each side in many cases. Primarily of interest to the MidOceanRidge feature, where it is used for the purpose of a richer description.

Not a time-dependent property because, for MidOceanRidge at any rate, that's insanity. A MidOceanRidge -generates- crust. For other boundary features, like SubductionZone, this property is only really used as annotation, (i.e. "this SZ is mostly consuming plate 541") and doesn't need to be over-complex.

This property doesn't support multiple plateIds per side for similar reasons to the ones above; in the case of MidOceanRidge, the usefuless of this property hinges on the potential to e.g. interpolate between both sides of the MOR and determine velocity. If more than one plateId per side were supported, topology would have to be taken into consideration, and pieces would have to move at different rates - and so the MOR would have to be broken up into segments, PLATES style. Perhaps when we get segmented MORs in the next release GPGIM, we can consider these extra possibilities. Until then, there's really no point in making this more complex than it needs to be.

Property.Name: gpml:rightUnit
Property.Description: Defines what is on the "Right" side of the contact, using an AbstractRockUnit.
Property.Comment: Assuming there is a suitable centerLineOf supplied, and understanding that the order of points in the line matters, we can establish a "Left" and "Right" side of the centerLine.
Particular implementations of AbstractRockUnit can include BasicRockUnit for simple free-text descriptions plus an extent, or more complex rock unit definitions.

Property.Name: gpml:seedPoints
Property.Description: The points from which the Flowline and MotionPath time-paths are generated.

Property.Name: gpml:shapefileAttributes
Property.Description: Attribute data imported from a Shapefile data file.
Property.Comment: As a large amount of data may be imported from Shapefiles, and there is not always an obvious way to map from (arbitrary) shapefile attributes to GPML property names, the user may need to set up a mapping that defines which shapefile attributes should be mapped, and the GPML property they are mapped to.

For example, the user may have a data set with "PLATEID" and "NAME" shapefile properties - these need to be mapped to the Feature's gpml:reconstructionPlateId and gml:name properties. Storing the mapping is important so that data can be returned to the original shapefile attributes later.

Property.Name: gpml:shipTrack
Property.Description: Optional reference to the MagneticAnomalyShipTrack that this pick originates from.

Property.Name: gpml:side
Property.Description: Indicates which direction leads to the continental crust.

Property.Name: gpml:slabEdgeType
Property.Description: The type of slab edge.

Property.Name: gpml:slabFlatLying
Property.Description: Whether the slab is flat lying or not.

Property.Name: gpml:slabFlatLyingDepth
Property.Description: The slab flat lying depth.

Property.Name: gpml:strikeSlip
Property.Description: The motion along the 'strike', or map-view line of the Fault.

Property.Name: gpml:subcategory
Property.Description: A free-form text string to optionally assign one or more subcategories to a feature type.
Property.Comment: Every gpml:Feature can optionally have one or more subcategories assigned to it. These are free-form text strings, and behave very similarly to the gml:name property; they also possess a 'codeSpace=' attribute to indicate what convention was used when assigning this subcategory to this Feature.

Use of the .subcategory property is entirely optional, however it is useful in several situations. There are many possible subcategories of real-world:Features, and these are highly subjective, depending on scientist, dataset, and area of research. Permitting arbitrary subcategorisation in the GPGIM has two benefits. One, GPlates can to continue to treat those real-world:Features as the appropriate gpml:Feature since any subcategory must have the same properties as the parent gpml:Feature. Two, it allows the scientist to have a finer grain of control over the categorisation of those real-world:Features without messing around with XML trying to extend the GPGIM.

An example: Seamount s and Guyot s. A Guyot is a special case of Seamount with a flat top. Functionally, they are identical. A problem arises; do we create a GPGIM feature for both of them, or just use Seamount for both cases? Some scientists and datasets may not care about the distinction, and wish to treat everything as a gpml:Seamount without being forced to go over the data and classify everything. On the other hand, a "Guyot Expert" would be very interested in the distinction between the two. The .subcategory property allows you to do this, without forcing you to.

Property.Name: gpml:subductionPolarity
Property.Description: Indicates the side of the line that the subducting slab is on.

Property.Name: gpml:subductionZoneAge
Property.Description: Age of subduction zone.

Property.Name: gpml:subductionZoneDeepDip
Property.Description: Subduction zone deep dig.

Property.Name: gpml:subductionZoneDepth
Property.Description: Subduction zone depth.

Property.Name: gpml:supersededRevision
Property.Description: Lists all revisions of this feature that were superseded by this one.
Property.Comment: This is a more accurate way of keeping track of the past, older revisions of a feature.

It will be purged on occasion to ensure files do not get bloated from many small changes. Newly superseded revisionId s get unshifted onto the front/head of the list, older ones are at the end/tail of the list.
A simple linear 'version number' would fail if a feature collection was concurrently modified by multiple users and then merged.

Property.Name: gpml:times
Property.Description: An array of time instants.
Property.Comment: Typically used to store the time instants at which Flowline and MotionPath features output points along the time-path.

Property.Name: gpml:totalReconstructionPole
Property.Description: A sequence of FiniteRotations and associated gml:TimeInstants, with FiniteRotationSlerp interpolation between them.

Property.Name: gpml:trail
Property.Description: HotSpots can be associated with zero, one, or more HotSpotTrails.
Property.Comment: HotSpots can be associated with zero, one, or more HotSpotTrails. Zero because there might not be any data about the movement of the HotSpot; One will be the most common case; and Two or more for disjoint HotSpotTrails. It is a reference to a HotSpotTrail, because HotSpotTrails may be rotated independently, and should be gpml:Features in their own right.

Property.Name: gpml:truncatedSection
Property.Description: Optional references to other Features that the user has indicated are supposed to be the same feature.
Property.Comment: While GPlates will treat each individual gpml:Feature separately, it is intended as a reminder that this Feature is part of a larger whole.

A common problem in PLATES datasets is the lack of any deformable geometry. This is often hacked around by creating multiple 'features' for the same real-world thing, for example, an Isochron getting subducted might have have been 'cut up' into multiple PLATES 'IS' features, to simulate the Isochron slowly disappearing. One day, this property will be used by a magical algorithm to undo all the 'cutting up' of features done in data sets for the purpose of hacking deformable geometry into PLATES.

Property.Name: gpml:unclassifiedGeometry
Property.Description: All geometry defined for the feature where the purpose is not given or is unclear.

Property.Name: gml:validTime
Property.Description: The period of time the feature is in existence.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:AbsoluteReferenceFrame
FeatureClass.Description: A means of describing the motion of plates over time, relative to a fixed point or frame.

FeatureClass.Name: gml:AbstractFeature
FeatureClass.Description: An identifiable real-world object in a selected domain of discourse.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:AbstractFeature
FeatureClass.Description: Highest-level abstract parent of all GPML Features.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:AbstractField
FeatureClass.Description: Abstract superclass for various field data, including stand-alone Contours and outlines.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:AbstractGeologicalContact
FeatureClass.Description: Abstract base for all Geological Contacts.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:AbstractGeologicalPlane
FeatureClass.Description: Abstract base for all Geological Surface Planes, including Surfaces such as Bedding Surfaces, Cleavage, intangible planes such as Fold Plane, as well as Contacts and Faults.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:AbstractRockUnit
FeatureClass.Description: Abstract base for all geological rock units.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:ArtificialFeature
FeatureClass.Description: Abstract base for geometry that has been arbitrarily created, or possibly derived from a TangibleFeature.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:AseismicRidge
FeatureClass.Description: Miscellaneous inactive ridge feature.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:BasicRockUnit
FeatureClass.Description: Basic definition of a geological rock unit.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Basin
FeatureClass.Description: Regional scale depression of erosional or structural origin.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Bathymetry
FeatureClass.Description: Sea floor depth data, including bathymetric contours and grids.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:ClosedContinentalBoundary
FeatureClass.Description: Rigid closed polygon continental crust boundary that can be reconstructed to any time.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:ClosedPlateBoundary
FeatureClass.Description: Rigid closed polygon plate boundary that can be reconstructed to any time.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Coastline
FeatureClass.Description: Present day coastline.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:ContinentalFragment
FeatureClass.Description: A fragment of continental crust that has become detached.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:ContinentalRift
FeatureClass.Description: A spreading rift on continental crust.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Craton
FeatureClass.Description: Large portion of a continental plate that has been relatively undisturbed since the Precambrian era and includes both shield and platform layers.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:CrustalThickness
FeatureClass.Description: Crustal thickness data, typically represented using grids, related to Isopach data.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:DisplacementPoint
FeatureClass.Description: A position used to build deforming regions.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:DynamicTopography
FeatureClass.Description: Elevation differences caused by the flow within the Earth's mantle.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:ExtendedContinentalCrust
FeatureClass.Description: Continental crust which has been pulled apart.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Fault
FeatureClass.Description: Fracture in a rock body along which observable relative displacement has occurred between adjacent blocks.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Flowline
FeatureClass.Description: Tracks plate motion away from spreading ridges over time using half-stage rotations.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:FoldPlane
FeatureClass.Description: Inferred plane of geological folding.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:FossilCollection_small
FeatureClass.Description: A collection of small fossils.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:FossilCollection_medium
FeatureClass.Description: A collection of medium fossils.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:FossilCollection_large
FeatureClass.Description: A collection of large fossils.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:FractureZone
FeatureClass.Description: Inactive fracture in the crust that was once part of a Transform boundary.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:FractureZoneIdentification
FeatureClass.Description: Pick to identify fracture zone.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:GeologicalLineation
FeatureClass.Description: Undefined linear region.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:GeologicalPlane
FeatureClass.Description: Surface plane indicator based on rock unit observations, e.g. Bedding and Cleavage planes.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:GlobalElevation
FeatureClass.Description: Merged bathymetric and topographic elevation data.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Gravimetry
FeatureClass.Description: Gravity grids, outlines, and contours.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:HeatFlow
FeatureClass.Description: Oceanic heat-flow data.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:HotSpot
FeatureClass.Description: Location in the mantle linked with high igneous activity.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:HotSpotTrail
FeatureClass.Description: Used to track the paleo-movement of HotSpots.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:InferredPaleoBoundary
FeatureClass.Description: Part of a plate boundary defined by hand for real-world geology that no longer exists.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:IslandArc
FeatureClass.Description: Type of volcanic arc formed by plate tectonics as an oceanic plate subducts under another and produces magma which rises to form the arc.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Isochron
FeatureClass.Description: Simple line defining points of equal age for oceanic crust.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:LargeIgneousProvince
FeatureClass.Description: An extensive region of basalts resulting from flood basalt volcanism.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:MagneticAnomalyIdentification
FeatureClass.Description: Magnetic 'pick' to identify age of oceanic crust based on magnetostratigraphic time-scale.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:MagneticAnomalyShipTrack
FeatureClass.Description: Ship Track data for Magnetic 'pick's.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Magnetics
FeatureClass.Description: Magnetic field feature for grid data and contours.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:MantleDensity
FeatureClass.Description: Density of the mantle, computed using Seismic Tomography.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:MeshNode
FeatureClass.Description: Global positions to calculate plate velocities at.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:MidOceanRidge
FeatureClass.Description: A spreading rift on oceanic crust.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:MotionPath
FeatureClass.Description: Tracks absolute plate motion over time.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:NavdatSample
FeatureClass.Description: Abstract base class representing a sample from the North American Volcanic and Intrusive Rock Database (NAVDAT).

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:NavdatSampleMafic
FeatureClass.Description: A sample from the NAVDAT database with mafic chemical composition.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:NavdatSampleIntermediate
FeatureClass.Description: A sample from the NAVDAT database with chemical composition intermediate between mafic and felsic.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:NavdatSampleFelsicLow
FeatureClass.Description: A sample from the NAVDAT database with low felsic chemical composition.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:NavdatSampleFelsicHigh
FeatureClass.Description: A sample from the NAVDAT database with high felsic chemical composition.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:OceanicAge
FeatureClass.Description: Age of seafloor, for contours and grids.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:OldPlatesGridMark
FeatureClass.Description: Backwards-compatibility with PLATES "GR" code.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Ophiolite
FeatureClass.Description: Uplifted oceanic crust attached to edges of continental plates.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:OrogenicBelt
FeatureClass.Description: A linear or arcuate zone on a regional scale which has undergone compressional tectonics.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:PassiveContinentalBoundary
FeatureClass.Description: Border line between oceanic and continental crust.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Pluton
FeatureClass.Description: A body of intrusive igneous rock.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:PoliticalBoundary
FeatureClass.Description: A political boundary.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:PolygonCentroidPoint
FeatureClass.Description: The centroid of a polygon used when meshing a deforming region that contains non-deforming interior blocks.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:PseudoFault
FeatureClass.Description: Fault-like contact caused by ridge propagation.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Raster
FeatureClass.Description: Generic multi-band, geo-referenced gridded image data.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:ReconstructableFeature
FeatureClass.Description: Parent of all GPML Features we may want to associate with a plateId and are reconstructable.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:ReconstructionFeature
FeatureClass.Description: Top-level abstract class that all rotations inherit from.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:RockUnit_carbonate
FeatureClass.Description: A carbonate rock unit.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:RockUnit_siliciclastic
FeatureClass.Description: A siliciclastic rock unit.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:RockUnit_evaporite
FeatureClass.Description: An evaporite rock unit.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:RockUnit_organic
FeatureClass.Description: An organic rock unit.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:RockUnit_chemical
FeatureClass.Description: A chemical rock unit.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:RockUnit_plutonic
FeatureClass.Description: A plutonic rock unit.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:RockUnit_volcanic
FeatureClass.Description: A volcanic rock unit.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:RockUnit_metamorphic
FeatureClass.Description: A metamorphic rock unit.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:RockUnit_indeterminate_igneous
FeatureClass.Description: An indeterminate_igneous rock unit.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Roughness
FeatureClass.Description: Roughness data computed from Gravity grids.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:ScalarField3D
FeatureClass.Description: Generic 3D field of scalar values representing arbitrary sub-surface data.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Seamount
FeatureClass.Description: Igneous cone-shaped mountain that is below sea level.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:SedimentThickness
FeatureClass.Description: Isopach data indicating sediment thickness using grids and/or contours.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:SlabEdge
FeatureClass.Description: A slab edge.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:SmallCircle
FeatureClass.Description: A global position and small circle radius for small circle visualisations.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:SpreadingAsymmetry
FeatureClass.Description: Asymmetry in sea-floor spreading rate.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:SpreadingRate
FeatureClass.Description: Sea-floor spreading rate.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Stress
FeatureClass.Description: Stress grids and contour data.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:SubductionZone
FeatureClass.Description: A zone of descending lithospheric plate.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Suture
FeatureClass.Description: Large scale structural feature associated with continental collision, separating crust that once belonged to two different plates.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:TangibleFeature
FeatureClass.Description: Abstract base for real geological features (compare with 'ArtificalFeature').

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:TectonicSection
FeatureClass.Description: Superclass to group ridgelike and related tectonic features together.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:TerraneBoundary
FeatureClass.Description: Regional scale miscellaneous contact line between two rock units.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:TimeVariantFeature
FeatureClass.Description: Abstract base class for all features that have a valid time period (compared to instantaneous features).

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Topography
FeatureClass.Description: Elevation data, including topographic contours and grids.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:TopologicalClosedPlateBoundary
FeatureClass.Description: A plate boundary formed by rubber-banding vertex lists, which are obtained by intersecting the geometry of other features.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:TopologicalFeature
FeatureClass.Description: Abstract base class for features that topologically reference geometries from other features.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:TopologicalNetwork
FeatureClass.Description: A triangulated region inside a topological boundary, comprising internal constraint geometries and excluding interior polygons, used to calculate velocities in deforming regions.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:TopologicalSlabBoundary
FeatureClass.Description: A topological closed boundary around a subducting slab.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:TotalReconstructionSequence
FeatureClass.Description: A sequence of total reconstruction poles for a specific fixed/moving plate pair.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Transform
FeatureClass.Description: Regional scale strike-slip plate boundary.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:TransitionalCrust
FeatureClass.Description: Undefined region between continental crust and oceanic crust.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Unconformity
FeatureClass.Description: Surface of contact between two differing rock units.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:UnknownContact
FeatureClass.Description: Regional scale unknown geological contact line.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:VirtualGeomagneticPole
FeatureClass.Description: Magnetic pole location consistent with the observed direction of remanence at a particular location.

FeatureClass.Name: gpml:Volcano
FeatureClass.Description: An opening in the crust, which allows magma to escape from below.
